chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: The &PRODNAME; service responds to events by changing server capacity to meet current needs. This ability to expand the cloud server configuration in response to increased workload means that you can begin with a minimal cloud configuration and grow only when the cost of that growth is justified.

chapter.title: Core Concepts
chapter.para: Rackspace supports &PROD;, an API-based tool that automatically scales resources as a response to an increase or decrease in overall workload based on user-defined thresholds.

&PROD; functions by linking these services:
Rackspace Cloud Monitoring
&PROD; API
Load-balanced cloud servers, such as Rackspace Cloud Load Balancers working with Cloud Servers
You can set up a schedule for launching Autoscale or define an event that is triggered by Cloud Monitoring. You can also specify a minimum and maximum number of cloud servers, the amount of resources you want to increase or decrease and the thresholds in Cloud Monitoring that triggers the scaling activities.

section.title: Basic Workflow
section.para: Rackspace Autoscaling works the following way:

listitem.para: In Cloud Monitoring, you configure alarms that are triggered when a high utilization of resources occurs.
When Cloud Monitoring sets off an alarm for high utilization of resources within a group, a webhook is triggered.

The webhook launches the Rackspace Autoscale service, which looks up the policy that has been defined in accordance with the webhook. This policy determines the amount of cloud servers that need to be added or removed in case the alarm is triggered.

section.para: Scale down events remove the oldest server in the group.

The Rackspace Autoscale service supports a cooldown feature. By configuring cooldown periods between triggers, you can control how quickly Autoscale scales up toward the scaling group's maximum size or down toward the scaling group's minimum size. A cooldown is a period during which no other scaling activity occurs.

Cooldowns work the following way:
Cooldowns allow some time for the initial scaling response to take effect, potentially resolving the situation that triggered the policy. When a scaling policy is triggered, cooldown periods begin for both the scaling policy and the group.
While the cooldown is active, any additional requests to the group or to the specific policy are ignored.
After the cooldown period ends, if Cloud Monitoring still detects the situation that triggered the initial scaling activity, another alarm triggers another round of scaling activity.

&PROD; does not configure anything within a server. You must configure your services to function properly when each server is started. We recommend automating your servers' startup processes with Chef or a similar tool.

section.title: Sample Use Case
section.para: Let's consider the following scenario:

A scaling group consists of five cloud servers.
Cloud Monitoring is configured to monitor the CPU usage of the five cloud servers.
Monitoring is configured to trigger an alarm when CPU utilization for any server within the group is at 90%.
The alarm triggers a webhook that has been previously configured.
When the webhook is activated, Autoscale receives the alert and executes the policy associated with the webhook: "When this webhook is triggered, create five servers according to the launch configuration, and add them to the load balancer."
Autoscale initates creation of those servers within the scaling group.
Autoscale can also work in the opposite direction. A policy can say "When this webhook is triggered, scale down by five servers."

chapter.title: Autoscale Components
chapter.para:
&PROD; consists of the following components:
Scaling Group Configuration
Launch Configuration
Scaling Policies

section.title: Scaling Group Configuration
section.para: The scaling group configuration specifies the basic elements of the Autoscale configuration. It manages how many servers can participate in the scaling group.

The group configuration specifies the following items:
Group Name
Group Cooldown
Minimum number of entities required in the scaling group
Maximum number of entities allowed in the scaling group
Within the group configuration, group cooldown describes, in seconds, how long the group must wait after a scaling policy is triggered before another request for scaling is accepted.

section.title: Launch Configuration
section.para: The launch configuration manages the process of creating new servers. It specifies what type of server image will be started on launch, what flavor the new server is, and which load balancer the new server connects to.

The launch configuration specifies the following items:
Launch Configuration Type
Launch Server (For the Preview release, this is the only configuration type.)
Server - specifies details about the server
Name
flavorRef
imageRef (This is the ID of the Cloud Server image to start.)
Load Balancer- specifies details about the load balancer
loadBalancerID
port

section.title: Scaling Group Policies
section.para: Scaling group policies specify how to modify the scaling group and its behavior. You can specify multiple policies to manage a scaling group.
Scaling policies specify the following:

listitem.para: Name of the scaling policy
Change value (incremental or per cent)
Policy cooldown time (in seconds)
Webhook execution (auto-generated)

chapter.title: Using the &PROD; API
chapter.para: You can create a autoscaling group by following the steps described in this chapter.
There are several options for sending requests through an API:

listitem.para: Developers and testers can use cURL, the command-line tool from http://curl.haxx.se/. With cURL you can send HTTP requests and receive responses from the command line.
If you prefer a more graphical interface, the ReST client for Firefox also works for testing API calls. For more information, see https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/restclient/.
You can also download and install rest-client from http://code.google.com/p/rest-client/. Test-client is a Java application that lets you test ReSTful web services.

tip.para: If you want to try these steps in your own environment, you can use http://docs.autoscale.apiary.io/ to generate cURL commands.

section.title: Authenticate
section.para: As with all Rackspace APIs, before you can use the Autoscale API you must authenticate with your Rackspace credentials.

listitem.para: When you authenticate, you submit your credentials to the Rackspace Cloud Identity Service.
If your credentials are valid, the Identity Service responds with your Service Catalog, which includes your token, token ID, user ID, and token tenant ID.
To make requests of &PROD;, you must use your token tenant ID, also known as the tenantID.

section.para: If you subscribe to many Rackspace services, your Service Catalog response might be lengthy. For an example of an annotated Service Catalog response, showing how to recognize the token and other elements in both JSON and XML formats, see http://docs.rackspace.com/auth/api/v2.0/auth-client-devguide/content/Sample_Request_Response-d1e64.html.
After you have your token, you can use it to identify yourself to &PRODNAME; and other services.

tip.para: For detailed information about the Rackspace Cloud Identity Service, visit http://docs.rackspace.com/auth/api/v2.0/auth-client-devguide/content/QuickStart-000.html.

section.para: To authenticate access to Rackspace Cloud services, you issue an authentication request to the Rackspace Cloud Identity Service, which is an implementation of the OpenStack Keystone Identity Service v2.0.

important.para: Multiple Rackspace Cloud Identity Service endpoints exist. You may use any endpoint, regardless of where your account was created.

section.title: Create Scaling Policies
section.para: You can use the Autoscale API to create and manage the scaling policies for your scaling group. Create a scaling policy by submitting a POST request that contains the tenantID that you obtained during the Authentication step and the groupID that you obtained during the Create and Manage a Scaling Group step.
You can specify multiple policies to manage your scaling group.

note.para: Executing a scaling policy always returns a 202 Accepted status. This status indicates that the scaling policy was executed but does not indicate whether the execution successfully caused the scaling group to scale. If some element of the configuration is invalid, scaling can fail even if the scaling policy is executed.

section.title: Delete a Scaling Group
section.para: You can use the Auto Scale API to deactivate and delete one or more scaling groups. Your options for deleting the scaling group depend on whether your scaling group has active entities or not.

note.para: You cannot delete a scaling group when it has active entities associated with it.

section.para: When a group contains no servers, you can eliminate the group by sending a DELETE request to its group ID.
The following three options are possible for deleting a scaling group:

listitem.para: If there are no active entities in your configuration, use the DELETE request to delete the scaling group.
If there are active entities in your configuration, update your scaling group configuration by submitting a PUT request and setting the minEntities and maxEntities parameters to 0.
Force the deletion of your group by submitting a DELETE request and setting the force parameter to true.

chapter.title: Frequently Asked Questions
chapter.para: Q: How much does the Rackspace Autoscale service cost?
A: Autoscale is a free service for Cloud Monitoring customers.
Q: How do I know that I'm being billed for Autoscale events?
A: Autoscale will feature an advanced Audit Log that tracks when Rackspace takes actions on a user's behalf.
Q: Can I use Autoscale across data centers?
A: No, you will need to create separate scaling groups for different data centers. The policies for these scaling groups can be triggered across data centers.
Q: How does Autoscale moderate conflicting events?
A: Cooldown timers are built into the Scaling Group and the individual scaling policies, so that the user can prevent too many servers from being created or deleted too quickly.
Q: Can I suspend servers and restore them quickly to the same IP address?
A: Autoscale will not suspend and restore servers to the same IP address. Servers will be restored to a different IP address.
Q: Can I scale up servers in a particular order? (i.e. spinning up a DB server before a web server)
A: Autoscale will not handle scaling up servers, databases, load balancers, etc... in a particular order. This will be handled by Checkmate and Workflow.
Q: Will Autoscale integrate with image services or other automation services, such as Chef or Puppet?
A: Autoscale is service-agnostic and API based, so it will work well with these services but will not explicitly integrate with them.
Q: When a server is automatically created it is attached to a load balancer. Is it possible to bring up a server(s) that is not attached to a load balancer?
A: Yes, you do not require a load balancer as part of the launch configuration, but you will have to configure how your servers get requests.
Q: Multiple scaling policies can be associated to the same scaling group. How is the "correct" policy selected when servers are generated?
A: The "handle" for each policy is defined by a construct called "webhook" which is a URL endpoint you need to call to invoke the policy execution.
Q: What is the minimum amount of time you can set a cool down for?
A: 5 minutes.
Q: What is the maximum limit you can set a cool down for?
A: There is no maximum cool down limit.
Q: What is a "group"?
A: It is a construct that contains the configuration for spinning up of individual servers and has one or more associated policies which describe what actions to take when the policy is activated.
Q: Do the servers that I'm going to automatically scale up have to be associated with a group? If so, why?
A: Yes. A scaling policy is associated with a specific group and we want to "manage" all the scaled up servers for health and monitoring in aggregate so they need to be a part of the group.
Q: The number of servers that can be scaled up with a group is limited to 25. How can I auto-scale beyond 25 servers?

A: That limitation is for a load balancer. If you need to auto-scale beyond 25 servers, add more than one autoscaling group, each associated with a load balancer and if needed create a pyramid of load balancers.
Q: Can I create an autoscale group with no servers in it?
A: Right now, you need at least one server in the Autoscale group. This is a requirement of the load balancer.
Q: Are monitoring rules for the entire cluster or can you specify specific servers in the cluster?
A: The checks and alarms will be written and specified within the launch configuration and then submitted to the newly created entities. There are no specific rules for specific servers.
Q: Will we drain connections on a node behind a load balancer as a service (LBaaS) before removing it from a pool?
A: We remove the server from the load balancer before we send the delete command. At present, we do not drain connections. But we are working on this.
Q: Will we use the default threshold set by monitoring as a service (MaaS) for each check to trigger a scale up?
A: This threshold will be defined with the alerting language in MaaS.
Q: Will we be recording the history of a scale for a customer?
A: There will be an audit log that shows scaling history, triggers, and user changes.
Q: Will there be an easy path for customers to come from other autoscaling products such as Rightscale?
A: We won't be able to migrate a users configurations from other providers.
